body: @shy-share The article you posted may talk about anonymous memory regions.  For file-backed memory area, mlock should be the behavior discussed in the redhat doc.

> > 细节

> Hi, do you mean to apply for a free available port as follows:
> 
> ```
>             ServerSocket serverSocket = new ServerSocket(0);
>             int port = serverSocket.getLocalPort();
> ```

Thank you for contributing!

It seems that the only way to find an available port is try to occupy a port using 0 and release it, but this approach is not thread-safe. You could get more information from the [deprecation of SocketUtils#findAvailableTcpPort](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-framework/issues/28052)

>  only way to find an available port is try to occupy a port using 0 and release it, but this approach is not thread-safe.

No, we should not use this approach. Modify the main source code to accept a configured listening port `0` and reflect/update the actual listening port in server-config objects. Use the config in test cases as we do in `RemotingServerTest`

It's about HEART_BEAT validation. See https://github.com/apache/rocketmq/blob/a1bfe1afce40c08083cae770b777aa2c9067479d/acl/src/main/java/org/apache/rocketmq/acl/plain/PlainAccessValidator.java#L90-L98

In your case, consumer subscribes TopicTest and TopicTestV2 whose HEART_BEAT rpc will contain these two topic which need SUB permission. Thus acl will reject HEAT_BEAT, so TopicTestV2 cannot get any message. In other word, TopicTestV2 is influenced by TopicTest.

> OK, thank you. If I want to realize that a consumer group subscribes to multiple topics, but the permissions of each topic are different. Permissions are not affected. Is there a good implementation plan?

I'm afraid not. HEART_BEAT is the RPC composed of all the subscription topics. You can use the mode that a group subscribes to a topic instead.
